ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.1.2_0: At that time monks who had completed the rainy-season residence were staying in wilderness dwellings.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.1.3_0: Thieves who were active during the month of Kattika attacked the monks, thinking,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.1.6_0: After giving a teaching, the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.1.7_0: “Monks, I allow monks who are staying in wilderness dwellings to store one of their three robes in an inhabited area.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.1_0: Knowing that the Buddha had made this allowance, monks stored one of their three robes in inhabited areas, and they stayed apart from them for more than six days.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.2_0: The robes were lost, destroyed, burnt, and eaten by rats.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.3_0: As a consequence those monks became poorly dressed.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.5_0: why they were so poorly dressed,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.6_0: The monks told other monks what had happened
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.7_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.8_0: “How can those monks store one of their three robes in an inhabited area and then stay apart from it for more than six days?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.9_0: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.10_0: “Is it true, monks, that some monks do this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.13_0: “... How can those foolish men store one of their three robes in an inhabited area and then stay apart from it for more than six days?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.14_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.15_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.16.1_0: ‘There are wilderness dwellings that are considered risky and dangerous. After observing the Kattika full moon that ends the rainy season, a monk who is staying in such a dwelling may store one of his three robes in an inhabited area, if he so desires, so long as he has a reason for staying apart from that robe.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.17_0: He should stay apart from that robe for six days at the most.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np29:1.2.17_1: If he stays apart from it beyond that, except if the monks have agreed, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
